{{Infobox musical artist | name = Lil' Ed Williams | image = Lil' Ed Williams and the Blues Imperials at the 2008 Ottawa Bluesfest (a).jpg | caption = Lil' Ed Williams at the [[Ottawa Bluesfest]] in 2008. | image_size = | background = solo_singer | birth_name = | alias = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1955|4|18|mf=y}}
[[Chicago]], [[Illinois]], [[United States]] | death_date = | origin = | instrument = [[Guitar]], [[Human voice|vocals]] | genre = [[Chicago blues]], [[electric blues]], [[contemporary blues]] | occupation = [[Guitarist]], [[singing|singer]], [[songwriter]] | years_active = Early 1980s-present | label = [[Alligator Records|Alligator]], [[Earwig Music Company|Earwig Music]] | associated_acts = Lil' Ed Williams and the Blues Imperials | website = [http://www.alligator.com/artists/lil-ed-and-the-blues-imperials/ Link] }} '''Lil' Ed Williams''' (born April 18, 1955, [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]], [[United States]]) is an [[United States|American]] [[blues]] [[guitarist]], [[singing|singer]] and [[songwriter]]. With his backing band, the Blues Imperials, [[slide guitar]]ist Williams has built up a loyal following. ==Biography== Williams and his half-brother James "Pookie" Young, received childhood encouragement and tutelage from their uncle, [[J. B. Hutto]], and by 1975 the half-siblings had formed the first version of the Blues Imperials. A decade later and [[Alligator Records]] offered them the chance to record for a forthcoming [[compilation album]]. In the event they cut a full album's worth of material that was released as ''Roughhousin''' (1986).{{cite web|author=Eugene Chadbourne |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/lil-ed-williams-mn0000825066/biography |title=Lil' Ed Williams | Biography |publisher=AllMusic |date=1955-04-18 |accessdate=2014-01-27}} They then appeared at [[music festival]]s and toured widely. Their second album release was entitled, ''Chicken, Gravy & Biscuits'' (1989), and their third LP, ''What You See is What You Get'' was issued in 1992. At this point the group disbanded, while Williams issued two [[solo (music)|solo]] albums; ''Keep On Walking,'' followed by ''Who's Been Talking'' (1998), the latter with [[Willie Kent]]. In 1999 the release of ''Get Wild'' marked the group's reunion, and has been followed in subsequent years with ''Heads Up'' (2002), ''Rattleshake'' (2006), and ''Full Tilt (2008) .{{cite web|author=Sandra Brennan |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/lil-ed-the-blues-imperials-mn0000275779/biography |title=Lil' Ed & the Blues Imperials | Biography |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2014-01-27}} In June 2008, Williams and the Blues Imperials appeared at the [[Chicago Blues Festival]].[http://www.americanfolkfestival.com/assets/Lil_Ed__The_Blues_Imperials.pdf ]{{dead link|date=January 2014}} The same year Williams guested on [[Magic Slim]]'s album, ''Midnight Blues''. In June 2009, Williams appeared as a guest on the radio quiz game show, produced by [[Chicago Public Radio]] and [[National Public Radio]], ''[[List of Wait Wait... Don't Tell Me! episodes (2009)|Wait Wait... Don't Tell Me!]]'' In 2013, Lil' Ed Williams and the Blues Imperials were nominated for a [[Blues Music Award]] in the 'Band' category.{{cite web|url=https://blues.org/#ref=bluesmusicawards_nominees|title=Blues Music Awards Nominees - 2013 - 34th Blues Music Awards|publisher=Blues.org|accessdate=2013-03-21}} They were nominated in the 'Band of the Year' category again in 2014.{{cite web|url=http://blues.about.com/od/bluesawards/a/2014-Blues-Music-Awards.htm |title=2014 Blues Music Awards Nominees and Winners |publisher=Blues.about.com |date= |accessdate=2014-05-16}} ==Discography== ===Lil' Ed Williams and the Blues Imperials=== *''Roughhousin''' (1986) - [[Alligator Records|Alligator]] *''Chicken, Gravy and Biscuits'' (1989) - Alligator *''What You See is What You Get'' (1992) - Alligator *''Get Wild'' (1999) - Alligator *''Heads Up'' (2002) - Alligator *''Rattleshake'' (2006) - Alligator *''Full Tilt'' (2008) - Alligator{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/lil-ed-the-blues-imperials-mn0000275779/discography |title=Lil' Ed & the Blues Imperials | Discography |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2014-01-27}} *''Jump Start'' (2012) - Alligator ===Solo=== *''Keep on Walkin''' (1996) - [[Earwig Music Company|Earwig Music]] *''Who's Been Talking'' (1998) - Earwig Music ==See also== *[[List of Chicago blues musicians]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{commons category}} {{Authority control|VIAF=67974186}} {{Persondata | NAME = Williams, Lil' Ed | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = Blues guitarist, singer and songwriter | DATE OF BIRTH = April 18, 1955 | PLACE OF BIRTH = [[Chicago]], [[Illinois]], [[United States]] | DATE OF DEATH = | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Williams, Ed}} [[Category:1955 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American blues guitarists]] [[Category:American blues musicians]] [[Category:American blues singers]] [[Category:American male singers]] [[Category:Songwriters from Illinois]] [[Category:Musicians from Chicago, Illinois]] [[Category:Slide guitarists]]
